Great videos.  I have just discovered them and really enjoy them. I work on infectious disease for a living. R0 is in part determined by the period of infectivity. In this video you talk about modeling an infection with one day infection vs two day infection. It seem that you are inferring the one day infectious period would be “less infectious.”  In that case, with all else equal, the R0 cannot remain the same. Setting your RO at a specific number but changing the period of infection would, in practice, indicate that despite a longer period of illness, people are infectious for the same amount of time. I recognize this is just a model, but if you intended to reflect different “infectiousness” I think using a fixed R0 would not work.  I could just be misunderstanding what you said. Still cool work!

On my case, I simulated the infection with a multiagent system with Jason language (AgentSpeak) for a population rounding 30.000 agents. I'm glad to see my results were so similar to yours. I worked with the same disease model SIR but I modified it, including Dead as a state and changing the ecuations, and also simulating the possibility of infection the same way, as agents leaving his house on certain days depending on his features as age, sex, etc.

Slight correction. Immunity is based on the type of infection and the rate of mutation. Bacterial infections tend to have lower levels of Immunity but are less infectious generallyspeaking, while viruses have high rates of infections and tend to have permanent Immunity. There are some cases of inherited Immunity as well. This does not apply to covid or the model, but it is interesting to note that the bubonic plague created inherited Immunity. Those who got the infection normally died, while those with a genetic anomaly did not cross the threshold for death. The science behind diseases and Immunity is both hard to understand and fun to learn about. Long story short loved the video and getting to experience learning on the topic again.

It would start with someone in Wuhan, and then spread to other people that they contact based on a few factors: indoors/outdoors/ventilation quality; duration of contact; length of time since initial exposure, for example. If they are indoors together with poor ventilation for 60 minutes on day 5 post exposure, then the probability that the contacted people get infected is 90%, and the probability goes down as each factor moves towards the more favorable outcome.

Although this is a great simplified model to demonstrate the fundamental ideas of how infectious diseases affect populations, in real life, it does become much more complicated. It is true that a vaccine helps us reach the point where people become immune faster than new susceptible people enter the population. However, missing from this model is how easily the virus mutates.

You can essentially model viral mutation by multiplying the chance of mutation per infection by the number of infected individuals. Multiply that by the chance that a mutation allows the virus to infect immune people, and you can effectively see at each stage of the pandemic's life cycle what the chances are that new strains will emerge that evade the vaccine and spark a new pandemic.

This is how diseases like the seasonal flu remain endemic, despite new vaccines being invented each year: the number of people already infected with the influenza virus reached a critical mass before there was ever a vaccine that new strains distinct enough to evade each new vaccine continue to emerge. Part of this has to do with the fact that the mutation rate itself was one of the things that was able to mutate, meaning we essentially reached a point where even a small population of infected individuals is enough to allow the virus to mutate and reemerge every year.

The only way to prevent a post-vaccine endemic COVID-19 is to vaccinate enough people quickly enough that, even if the mutation rate is already high, the number of infected individuals decreases quickly enough to overcome the chance of vaccine evasion. Unfortunately, due to corporate greed and an unwillingness to use political power to massively expand vaccine production/distribution, we're already seeing that endemic COVID-19 is inevitable. Vaccination rates in the US are pretty good, but billions of people in poorer countries are not receiving the vaccine in high enough quantities to prevent the virus from reaching the endemic stage there--and eventually, every other country.

I know it's a little dark, but it would've been nice to show a graph of dead blobs. Covid has a crude 3-4% mortality rate, which is reported case numbers divided by reported covid deaths, which is most likely low balling since many countries have been reported to have drastically understated their numbers, and many symptoms of covid, such as strokes or immune deficiency aren't considered "covid deaths", but it would've been cool to see how that would've affected the graph, such that once the infection duration is over, a blob has a 3-4% chance to die, thus making the herd immunity to be less effective. Furthermore herd immunity is hardly ever permanent, so it would've been cool to have a random chance to last from only a few days after all the way til you die of old age, thus making a secondary infection possible. I get that you didn't want to make a video featuring death, especially since these blobs are representative of human beings, not just some creatures, and because many people are stressed or scared, but I think it would've been really fascinating to see it demonstrated as accurately as possible. I hope that someday down the line, once covid is long gone, you might be able to remake or go into more details for simulations like these. Still a truly great video

This simulation shows how an R0 factor of 2.5 would require a vaccination rate of 60% to bring the viral infection to a near zero eradication rate.

This is fascinating. Especially when seeing the changes of having lower values of R0

Conversely, an R0 value that is higher, would require a higher rate of vaccination to effectively manage the virus outbreaks.

While this is a basic simulation, what the trends lead me to conclude, is that if I wanted a justification to force the injection of "vaccination" on the populace of the world, I could reverse the infection formulae and figure out the ideal R0 value a virus would have to have in order to produce a severe enough outbreak to then "beg" the solution and require everyone take it.

Since it has come out that the Wuhan bat virus was modified in a lab via "gain of functoon" research, and that the predicted R0 factor peddled by the media was 4 to 4.5....somehow i feel this was the perfect number to get back-fed into these simulations to "justify" the argument that everyone must get vaccinated....even though the actual impact of this flu is rather minimal on people, in terms of actual death rates and how badly people get sick.

So, you said that immunity isn't inherited, but this isn't entirely true. What about passively acquired immunity? In this case a baby acquires the immunity of the mother for the first few years of life, provided that the mother breastfed. If the baby is on formula it seems to last around 6 months. How would the inclusion of passively acquired immunity affect these models?

Also, what about asymptomatic individuals who show no symptoms and also never recover but remain infectious? Typhoid Mary was a classic example of a carrier who, for the remainder of her life, was infected and infectious but never showed symptoms. I'm under the impression that it's very rare for a carrier to maintain the infection lifelong, even more rare than carriers themselves are, but it has been shown that carriers of covid-19 are testing positive several weeks later with only around 1 or 2% on average eventually developing symptoms if they were previously determined to be asymptomatic. This shows that the duration of the infection can be longer in a portion of the population that does not show symptoms, although not permanent in any known case that I'm aware of. So wouldn't your model have to account for an asymptomatic individual who was always infectious and never recovered? Or a group of individuals who were infectious for two to three weeks longer than the average, and along with that wouldn't we have to account for individuals who died of the infection and therefore are not infecting others as long as they could have?

Call so, there are a few issues with vaccine predictions. Most notably is the fact that mutations occur silver vaccine becomes ineffective against later strains. we see this all the time with flu Seasons. Occasionally a flu vaccine is released that is ineffective against the current season's flu because of a missed prediction. more seriously though is the fact that taking A vaccine has been shown to decrease the rate of increase of killer T-cells. That is to say, you still produce new killer T-cells, you just don't produce as many in relation to the number of vaccines you received. this means that while the vaccine protects you against the predicted strain you are, as a consequence of taking the vaccine, slightly less able to mount an effective immune response to what you are not protected against. in a given year there can be more than 50 different respiratory infections going around, more than just the common strain of the cold or flu, but if we vaccinated against all of it it would actually cause problems more than it would help. It's more than an issue of cost. If, for example, you wanted to eradicate all 2,000 ish strains of the common cold you would have to vaccinate 60% of the population 2000 times. the truth is that we have no idea what. Many vaccines would do to the body or what problems it could cause. I would infer though that if a population took an increasing number of vaccines it would actually lead to an outbreak of something else entirely. I'd be curious to see a simulation on that though.

a much better model than the vaccine model that I've seen is the blood serum model. That's what we used before vaccines existed, but in order to get the blood serum you have to extract it from an individual who recovered from the infection. It's Superior to vaccines in that you can give it to someone who is currently sick to treat them as a cure or you can use it as a vaccine equivalent without the issues of reduced immunity to other strains. Some years ago actually recall reading about a genetically modified tobacco plant that was used to produce synthetic blood serum, but it's been a while since I've heard any news about it so I don't really know if There were any problems with this approach though. Still, I would be very curious to see how a cereal approach might differ from a vaccine approach in these models. for example, suppose you wanted to eradicate the common cold and you had a cure ready to administer for all 2,000 strains and suppose you had sophisticated enough testing to know which individual was infected with which strain and could deliver this treatment within 3 days of infection whereas an untreated individual might take up to two weeks to stop being infectious. Would that be an effective strategy?

First, can every hospital and health care handle all the patient growth? (Cuz nobody can be able to recover by their own immunity and usually will lead to death if not treated properly, so a medical institution and infrastructure will be needed)
Second, vaccine need to be researched by the scientist and its require funding, technology, and time also dedication of the scientist (they must brave enough to risk their life)
Third, in a massive "sickness" condition is it possible to maintain stability in economy? (which mean our nation is in chaos condition, hard to maintain the well-being of society also the vaccine research, cuz everything isnt free)
Fourth, infectivity rate isnt based on probability but rather how the society obey the government advice, individual immune system/health condition, social activity, medical accessibility, understanding of the incubation process and all of it symptom (so one can decide to go for medical check up or not, undetected virus spread is very dangerous, especially if the virus is very infectious)
Fifth, instead of people recovered, actually theres a potential of mortality and this potential will become more potent/dangerous if the one who died is the health-labors
Sixth, misinformation also have contribution to the virus spread (cuz people act is based on information or knowledge, then hoax could create maltreatment which could spread the virus)

Another way people can help us by donating computer power. You can download folding@home or rossetta@home to help researchers with vaccine research for covid. Folding@home solves protein models that could potentially lead to a vaccine or treatment and rossetta@home makes models for the f@h to solve. These computer apps use your idle computing power so it won’t interfere with your computer when you’re using it. For Apple and android phones there is Dreamlab. When your phone is plugged in and you press the “power dreamlab” button you donate your phones computing power to help research for a covid drug or vaccine( dreamlab is typically used for cancer research but now they have a covid option ). There is also a computer game called foldit that you can play. You solve protein models to help fund drugs and vaccines for all kids of diseases(including covid).

The concept of herd immunity doesn't apply to COVID-19, because from what it appears to be people can get infected multiple times and then have to fight the disease multiple times, which is a battle either way. (A lot of people treating infected patients have died, presumably quite a few have gotten the virus multiple times.) There's no such thing as immunity == no susceptibility, it merely means your body should be able to produce antibodies when it gets sick again . The other issue at play why herd immunity tends to not work well in real world scenarios is due to a very big variety in how capable people their immune systems are in dealing with any virus. That's how healthy people end up on the intensive care. Even when there's no inheritance of immunity, you absolutely inherent a large part of what your immune system can be, even when you have to get sick multiple times to really 'train' it. The other issue is that for a herd immunity to work, you would still need to isolate the weak, which is pretty much impossible. You'd also have to be pretty sure there are enough healthy people that wouldn't die of the disease, where with a required 60% of people having gotten sick, this means most countries would end up with a LOT of elderly people sick and dying. Just about any country with a population ageing will have serious problems with any kind of herd immunity theory, as it would STILL result in a lot of elderly people dead. The short story is that isolation is the only solution for any disease that has no vaccine or cure / treatment. In terms of real world numbers, keep in mind that even in massive countries like the US literally only 1% ever has gotten the disease. Imagine that being 60x times more and imagine the current death toll being 60x worse or more. And you'd quickly realize herd immunity is a pretty ridiculous concept for a virus of this nature. It might be cool for influenza that barely would kill anyone. It's not useful for COVID-19.

For what it's worth.... in case there's a suggestion here, COVID-19 is not an endemic. It's not something that's as common as chickenpox in the UK. It's as rare as an ebola outbreak would be, which definitely is not an endemic. The definition of endemic is not related to 'time an infectious disease spreads around', but rather an infection that is constantly maintained at a baseline level, meaning you'd pretty much not get rid of it entirely. It's way too early to classify COVID-19 as endemic. Again, it has more in common with how rare malaria or ebola would be.

I'm curious about how we could model the economy during these simulations as well.

For example, maybe have the buildings survive by taking in a certain amount of currency supplied by individual blobs. Then try to simulate social distancing and have the blobs stay home once the epidemic reaches a certain threshold. When the epidemic is over, what does the city look like? What if blobs can only survive and live in homes if they have money for rent. How many blobs die of malnutrition and homelessness due to the epidemic, rather than the virus?

Maybe even simulate a government's decision making (forcing people to stay home, pretending it's nothing to worry about). And then see how both the economy, and the population is affected.

Which decisions ultimately result in the least deaths and infections, as well as the least impact on the economy? Which decision ultimately destroyed both? If one decision happens to save everyone, how badly is the economy damaged? If a decision saves the economy, how do the people suffer?

Maybe add a third option: do the people listen? What if the government picked the "best" choice based on our simulations above. Does it still minimize economic and health costs? or if the population refuses to listen to the government, is there any possible scenario where everyone can still be saved? All things considered, which combination of all these variables saves the most lives and money?
